page_analysis.text_content:
Gross vs. net lot area

Gross lot area is the size of the lot—from lot line to lot line.
Development potential is based on the net lot area and
while gross and net lot area are the same for most lots in
Palo Alto, there are some lots for which portions must be
excluded from the gross lot area to establish the net lot area.


Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:

• Street right-of-way (Area A of Fig 1 on this page)

• “Pole” portion of a flag lot (Area B of Fig 2 on this page)

• Creek channel (Area C of Fig 3 on this page)


Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements

Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”

Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions : creek easements


[Text associated with Fig 1]
Lot with
boundaries
that extend
into the
public ROW

The portion of the lot within the
public ROW must be subtracted
from the gross lot area.

Note: In some areas of Palo Alto, like
Barron Park, it is not unusual for the
lot to extend to the middle of the
street. However
purposes, the lot is defined by the
edge of the public street easement or
public right-of-way (ROW).
Dimensions for the public ROW are
available at the Development Center

easement

The portion of the lot within a
creek channel must be subtracted
from gross lot size.

Note: The channel or area to be
subtracted is defined by Santa Clara
Valley Water District’s easement or, if
there is no easement, the top-of-bank.
Determining the top-of-bank may
require a surveyor.

visual_elements.description: Figure 1 illustrates a 'street easement' exclusion. It shows a top-down view of a two-lane street with two cars. A lot's boundaries are shown extending into the street area, which is labeled 'Public ROW' (Right-of-Way). The portion of the lot within the street is shaded and labeled 'A', indicating it must be subtracted from the gross lot area. Explanatory text with arrows points to the relevant parts of the diagram.

Figure 2 illustrates 'flag-lot “poles”' exclusions. It shows two adjacent lots fronting a street. The left lot is a standard flag lot accessed via a private easement, which is noted as NOT being subtracted. The right lot is a 'flag lot with “pole”', where the 'pole' (a narrow strip of land providing access) is an integral part of the lot. This pole is shaded, labeled 'B', and identified as the portion that must be subtracted from the gross lot size.

Figure 3 illustrates 'creek easements' exclusions. It shows a lot adjacent to a creek. The portion of the lot that contains the creek channel is shaded and labeled 'C', indicating it must be subtracted from the gross lot size. The diagram labels the 'Top of bank' and indicates the width of the 'Creek easement'. A note explains that the area to be subtracted is defined by the water district's easement or the top-of-bank.

A legend or 'Key' located at the bottom-right of the page defines five visual symbols used in the diagrams: a solid line for 'Curb', a hatched line for 'Sidewalk', a dashed line for 'Lot lines', a wavy pattern for 'Creek', and a shaded box for 'Area that must be subtracted from gross lot area'.

additional_notes: The document is a clean, high-quality copy.
The page is numbered '3' in the bottom-right corner.

The overall layout consists of a main heading and introductory text, followed by a bulleted list that refers to three diagrams. The diagrams are arranged on the page with associated explanatory text and notes.

The note for Fig 2 has unusual line breaks and alignment: 'Private access easements / that provide access to / lots are NOT subtracted / the lot on which they occur.' This formatting is preserved in the transcription.
